title: Blog: Is your hospital participating in the CJR Program? If so, MedAssets-Precyse can help
body:
The Comprehensive Care for Joint Replacement (CJR) Model is now underway, with 860 hospitals in 67 metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) required to participate on all knee and hip replacements. It is important to note that CJR is just the first step in CMS' strategy to move 30 percent of current fee-for-service Medicare reimbursements to Alternative Payment Models by 2016, and 50 percent by 2018. 

Because this represents a fundamental shift in how hospitals will be reimbursed for these Medicare claims (MS DRGs 469 and 470), it is important for all healthcare organizations to understand the CJR program highlights and potential impact. To follow are the high points:

Hospitals are now accountable for spend that they don’t directly control over the full extent of the 90-day episode. No longer just financially accountable for the in-patient stay, they are accountable for all spend related to a 90-day lower extremity joint replacement episode.

Hospital margins for these procedures will be directly impacted by competitive hospitals within their regions. A bundled reimbursement for the entire episode will be based on a Target Price. CMS will define the target price based on three years of historical data where regional data is blended with hospital-specific claims data.

Hospitals will now be reimbursed based on cost and quality measures. The Target Price includes a 1.5% to 3.0% discount to CMS, depending upon quality performance.

Hospitals must meet a minimum composite quality score for reconciliation payment eligibility. Quality thresholds will be defined as a composite quality score based on performance of risk standardized complication rate for total hip arthroplasty (THA)/total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and HCAHPS Quality Assurance Guidelines survey results.

The net impact is that hospitals must meet price targets and quality thresholds to earn reconciliation payments. The payment and reconciliation in the CJR Model is based on an average spending during the 90-day episode. This is compared to hospital-level price targets, with specific stop-loss and stop-gain caps applied.

According to CMS, hip and knee replacements are the most common inpatient surgery for Medicare beneficiaries, and can require lengthy and costly recovery and rehabilitation periods. Its goal is to minimize the quality and cost variability among providers (ranges from $16,500 to $33,000) and reduce the overall reimbursement levels over time is the goal.

Because additional mandatory initiatives for other high-value DRGs are a certainty, all healthcare organizations should be preparing today to handle bundled payments and other value-based reimbursement initiatives. Getting the CJR program off to a successful start, and then sustaining the cost cutting and quality improvement measures across both acute and post-acute care will be critical.

MedAssets-Precyse has a comprehensive solution to address management of value-based reimbursement models such as CJR, with consulting services to ensure rapid implementation. The ‘speed to value’ of our approach is the ability to leverage a robust data and analytics capability to understand your CJR starting point, and how to meet the Target Price.

For more information on how our revenue cycle management solutions can help,  contact a MedAssets-Precyse specialist at solutions@nthrive.com or call 678.323.2500.

title: Kettering Health draws high turnout for presentation on Setting Patient Expectations at #NAHAM16
description: Jana Mixon, executive director of Access and Scheduling Services at Kettering Health Network, spoke to a near full house at the NAHAM Breakfast Symposia.
body:
Jana Mixon, executive director of Access and Scheduling Services at Kettering Health Network, spoke to a near full house at the NAHAM Breakfast Symposia.

Mixon and co-presenter Magan Butler-Coleman, vice president, Revenue Cycle Management Solutions at MedAssets-Precyse. discussed "Setting the Right Expectations while Delivering a Positive and Memorable Experience." To follow is a summary of their presentation:

State price transparency provisions differ nationally, and there are limited solutions and approaches in the market to address the transparency provisions. As a leading non-profit health system in the Dayton, OH area, Kettering Health Network continues to drive record annual point-of-service cash collections. This session will highlight why deploying innovative strategies in patient access solutions can help other organizations address emerging state transparency provisions while supporting our patients as they assume greater financial responsibility, with an ultimate goal of creating an optimal patient experience.

 Learning objectives for the session included: 

  • Highlight technology best practices that improve cash flow and collections.
  • Identify process improvement strategies to significantly impact upfront patient collections.
  • Provide successful training approaches that enhance staff effectiveness in point of service collections.
  • Define financial advocacy techniques to improve patient collections and satisfaction.

Stay tuned for more on this compelling discussion!

title: Visit MedAssets-Precyse booth #205 #NAHAM16. Don't Miss the Breakfast Symposia featuring Kettering Health Network
description: Don't miss our breakfast symposia featuring Kettering Health Network, May 26, 7:30-8:45 a.m., #NAHAM16. Jana Mixon, executive director, Access & Scheduling Services at Kettering, and, Magan Butler-Coleman, vice president, Revenue Cycle Solutions at MedAssets-Precyse, will speak about "Setting the right expectations while delivering a positive and memorable patient financial experience." In this session you'll learn how Kettering used innovative approaches to drive record point of service collections and support a leading-edge patient experience for their health system.
body: Don't miss our breakfast symposia featuring Kettering Health Network, May 26, 7:30-8:45 a.m., #NAHAM16. title: Ready or not, hospitals face mandatory bundling for joint replacement

But joint replacement isn't the only possible target. Hospitals are now on notice that Medicare will move ahead if they don't do it on their own.

title: ICD-10 two months In: For providers, a transition that came and went
description: To follow is the second of a two part series on the ICD transition by Healthcare Informatics. Says Paul Dufresne, patient account manager at Boston-based Partners HealthCare, the biggest concern leading into the transition was that everyone was mapping what they were doing in the ICD-9 world to try to get equivalent comparisons in ICD-10. “That was the approach that people chose. But that can be subjective, and it could lead to missed diagnoses,” Dufresne says. However, he adds, these mapping issues were not nearly as bad as Partners anticipated. “We were expecting big-time disasters, and it wasn’t like that at all.”
body: To follow is the second of a two part series on the ICD transition by Healthcare Informatics. Says Paul Dufresne, patient account manager at Boston-based Partners HealthCare, the biggest concern leading into the transition was that everyone was mapping what they were doing in the ICD-9 world to try to get equivalent comparisons in ICD-10. “That was the approach that people chose. But that can be subjective, and it could lead to missed diagnoses,” Dufresne says. However, he adds, these mapping issues were not nearly as bad as Partners anticipated. “We were expecting big-time disasters, and it wasn’t like that at all.”

title: First data flows from national registry tracking joint replacements
description: Hospitals can now access national data on hip and knee replacement surgeries thanks to an inaugural report published by the American Joint Replacement Registry. The first national medical procedure registry in the U.S., data will include basic information on roughly 43,000 joint surgeries in 2013. Hip and knee replacement surgeries are among the most common surgical procedures performed in the U.S. and require expensive revisions when they fail.
body: Hospitals can now access national data on hip and knee replacement surgeries thanks to an inaugural report published by the American Joint Replacement Registry. title: New ICD-10 code for Zika virus
description: The American Health Information Management Association now has an ICD-10 code for the birth defect-causing Zika virus: A92.8. On Feb. 5, as 11 states had reported travel-associated cases of the Zika virus, AHIMA sent an email to its members recommending they assign that code (for "other specified mosquito-borne viral fevers") to Zika cases.

description: According to a recent survey, the ICD-10 transition is negatively impacting inpatient and outpatient coder productivity at hospitals of all sizes and types.

title: Video: New IHI head talks about the key to population health Group
description: In this video Derek Feeley, the incoming head of the Institute for Healthcare Improvement, talks about the key to better population health.
body: In this video Derek Feeley, the incoming head of the Institute for Healthcare Improvement, talks about the key to better population health.

title: Today's physician alignment strategies require risk and clinical integration
description: Read how healthcare leaders are developing clinical integration models to address clinical and financial transformation.
body: Read how healthcare leaders are developing clinical integration models to address clinical and financial transformation.

title: How CMS Aims to Boost MSSP Participation
description: Some big changes proposed for the Medicare Shared Savings Program are drawing a measure of praise from healthcare providers and analysts.
body: Some big changes proposed for the Medicare Shared Savings Program are drawing a measure of praise from healthcare providers and analysts.

title: HHS releases 2016 Marketplace Affordability Snapshot
description: According to an HHS analysis, about eight out of 10 returning consumers will be able to buy a plan with premiums less than $100 dollars a month after tax credits. Across all markets in the 37 states, the cost of the benchmark plan will increase an average of 7.5 percent.
body: According to an HHS analysis, about eight out of 10 returning consumers will be able to buy a plan with premiums less than $100 dollars a month after tax credits. Across all markets in the 37 states, the cost of the benchmark plan will increase an average of 7.5 percent.

title: Looking afield: debt collection tips hospitals can borrow from banks
description: When Southwest Airlines was a fledgling company, it struggled with finding a way to outpace other airlines in a competitive environment. Legendary CEO Herb Kelleher believed Southwest could gain a competitive advantage by focusing on a critical key performance indicator: the time it takes to "turn a plane" (i.e., unload, clean, restock, refuel, reload new passengers, and taxi for take-off).
body: When Southwest Airlines was a fledgling company, it struggled with finding a way to outpace other airlines in a competitive environment. Legendary CEO Herb Kelleher believed Southwest could gain a competitive advantage by focusing on a critical key performance indicator: the time it takes to "turn a plane" (i.e., unload, clean, restock, refuel, reload new passengers, and taxi for take-off).

title: Trade deal disappoints drug makers, consumer groups
description: Will the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement help or hurt access to lifesaving drugs? It depends on who you ask. Read more in this analysis.
body: Will the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement help or hurt access to lifesaving drugs? It depends on who you ask. Read more in this analysis.

title: How to handle ICD-10 issues
description: Healthcare organizations can begin directing physicians who are struggling with the ICD-10 transition to a dedicated communications center in Baltimore.
body: Healthcare organizations can begin directing physicians who are struggling with the ICD-10 transition to a dedicated communications center in Baltimore.

title: In palliative care, comfort is the top priority
description: Palliative care became an approved medical specialty in 2007. Although the general public knows little about it, it has grown rapidly in hospitals. More than 70 percent now offer palliative care services, including 90 percent of those with more than 300 beds.
body: Palliative care became an approved medical specialty in 2007. Although the general public knows little about it, it has grown rapidly in hospitals. More than 70 percent now offer palliative care services, including 90 percent of those with more than 300 beds.

title: Why do doctors choose a $2,000 cure when a $50 one is just as good?
description: Andrew Lam, M.D., is a retinal surgeon, Assistant Professor at Tufts University School of Medicine, and author of "Saving Sight." In this article he discusses why physicians often choose more costly drugs even if other, less costly drugs, are proven to be as effective.
body: Andrew Lam, M.D., is a retinal surgeon, Assistant Professor at Tufts University School of Medicine, and author of "Saving Sight." In this article he discusses why physicians often choose more costly drugs even if other, less costly drugs, are proven to be as effective.

title: Creating clarity around meaningful use for public health
description: This article examines CMS' meaningful use criteria for public health and delves into alternate exceptions for eligible providers and hospitals, as outlined under the meaningful use modifications rule for public health reporting.
body: This article examines CMS' meaningful use criteria for public health and delves into alternate exceptions for eligible providers and hospitals, as outlined under the meaningful use modifications rule for public health reporting.

title: Participation not a choice for CCJR bundled-payment program
description: If your hospital is located in one of 67 geographically designated areas, including Los Angeles and New York City, you'll be required to participate in the Comprehensive Care for Joint Replacement (CCJR) model, which launches on January 1, 2016.
body: If your hospital is located in one of 67 geographically designated areas, including Los Angeles and New York City, you'll be required to participate in the Comprehensive Care for Joint Replacement (CCJR) model, which launches on January 1, 2016.

title: How is the Affordable Care Act impacting the labor market?
description: According to a recent study by the National Center for Policy Analysis, the ACA is having a positive impact on labor, versus encouraging employment of more part-time workers.
body: According to a recent study by the National Center for Policy Analysis, the ACA is having a positive impact on labor, versus encouraging employment of more part-time workers.

title: Why medical tech start-ups need to relate to seniors
description: While much of the latest technology is targeted to older adults it isn't necessarily designed for them. Read how the industry has failed on many new start-ups and what they are learning in the process about their geriatric audience.
body: While much of the latest technology is targeted to older adults it isn't necessarily designed for them. Read how the industry has failed on many new start-ups and what they are learning in the process about their geriatric audience.

title: New Ways for Patients to Get a Second Opinion
description: For many patients, it has become a routine part of the medical process: Get a diagnosis or treatment plan and then seek a second opinion. A growing number of online services are offering second opinions and some are seeing increasing patient demand for a second set of eyes.
body: For many patients, it has become a routine part of the medical process: Get a diagnosis or treatment plan and then seek a second opinion. A growing number of online services are offering second opinions and some are seeing increasing patient demand for a second set of eyes.

title: Is your organization turning value-based care into a business model?
description: Innovative providers are redesigning care models so that, despite financial pain in the short term, they'll achieve long-range success in a value-based care world.
body: Innovative providers are redesigning care models so that, despite financial pain in the short term, they'll achieve long-range success in a value-based care world.

title: Expect more health systems to get in the insurance game
description: In hopes of increasing revenue, more healthcare organizations are entering the health insurance business. Some are even hiring insurance executive to run their health plans. In this article, read the benefits and trade-offs organizations are encountering as they navigate this new space.
body: In hopes of increasing revenue, more healthcare organizations are entering the health insurance business. Some are even hiring insurance executive to run their health plans. In this article, read the benefits and trade-offs organizations are encountering as they navigate this new space.

title: Health improving for urban residents, but racial disparities persist
description: Residents in 27 of the nation's big cities are experiencing lower rates of cancer, diabetes and motor vehicle-accident deaths in 2012 compared with 2007, though African-Americans have not shared in many of these gains, according to a report from the Big Cities Health Coalition.
body: Residents in 27 of the nation's big cities are experiencing lower rates of cancer, diabetes and motor vehicle-accident deaths in 2012 compared with 2007, though African-Americans have not shared in many of these gains, according to a report from the Big Cities Health Coalition.

title: Cassidy-Whitehouse EHR certification bill released
description: A newly introduced bill could create "Consumer Reports-like" star ratings for electronic health record (EHR) systems, grading everything from usability to interoperability and security. How would you rank your system?
body: A newly introduced bill could create "Consumer Reports-like" star ratings for electronic health record (EHR) systems, grading everything from usability to interoperability and security. How would you rank your system?

title: Hospitals redesigning care delivery to best serve the changing needs of communities
description: American Hospital Association president challenges organizations to decide on a best path to serve their communities.
body: American Hospital Association president challenges organizations to decide on a best path to serve their communities.

title: Study puts a dollar value on the time spent waiting for the doctor
description: With patients bearing more of the cost for healthcare, time truly is money. Read about research from Harvard Medical School that calculates how many minutes patients spend seeking medical care - and the dollar value of their lost time.
body: With patients bearing more of the cost for healthcare, time truly is money. Read about research from Harvard Medical School that calculates how many minutes patients spend seeking medical care - and the dollar value of their lost time.

title: CMS posts new rule on Medicare data sharing, analysis
description: Some medical data miners may soon be allowed to share and sell Medicare and private-sector medical-claims data, as well as analyses of that data, under proposed regulations issued by CMS .
body: Some medical data miners may soon be allowed to share and sell Medicare and private-sector medical-claims data, as well as analyses of that data, under proposed regulations issued by CMS .

title: Communities collaborate to make a difference on health
description: Building coalitions within communities is one way to help drive behavioral changes and improve population health.
body: Building coalitions within communities is one way to help drive behavioral changes and improve population health.

title: Hospitals get new hope on RAC appeals backlog thanks to Court ruling
description: Hospitals persuaded a federal appeals court to give new life to their legal fight to force HHS to work more quickly through a backlog of disputed findings by Medicare's controversial recovery audit contractors.
body: Hospitals persuaded a federal appeals court to give new life to their legal fight to force HHS to work more quickly through a backlog of disputed findings by Medicare's controversial recovery audit contractors.

title: CMS falls $2.5 billion short on risk-corridor payments for health insurers
description: Insurers lose big as market stabilization programs come under risk.
body: Insurers lose big as market stabilization programs come under risk.

title: Hospitals redesigning care delivery to best serve changing needs of their communities @ahahospitals
description: American Hospital Association president challenges organizations to decide on a best path to serve their communities.
body: American Hospital Association president challenges organizations to decide on a best path to serve their communities.

title: Why ICD-10 Is Good for Radiology
description: Read this radiology viewpoint on why ICD-10 is good for radiology, especially as a bridge to improving health care long-term.
body: Read this radiology viewpoint on why ICD-10 is good for radiology, especially as a bridge to improving health care long-term.

title: Proposal to trim 340B payments may not move forward
description: A proposal to reduce the 340B Drug Pricing Program rates by 10% of the average sales price of the drugs was first raised in November by the congressional advisory panel. However, The Medicare Payment Advisory Commission may not move forward with this controversial proposal that would reduce Part B drug payment rates for hospitals participating in the 340B Drug Pricing Program.
body: A proposal to reduce the 340B Drug Pricing Program rates by 10% of the average sales price of the drugs was first raised in November by the congressional advisory panel. However, The Medicare Payment Advisory Commission may not move forward with this controversial proposal that would reduce Part B drug payment rates for hospitals participating in the 340B Drug Pricing Program.

title: SNF cost comparison report occupancy rates down, cash-on-hand increases
description: A decline in occupancy rates and an increase in days cash-on-hand are among the findings included in CliftonLarsonAllen's sweeping Skilled Nursing Facility Cost Comparison Report. Skilled nursing facilities saw a decrease in occupancy rates from 91.9% in 2010 to 90.4% in 2014, according to the report.
body: A decline in occupancy rates and an increase in days cash-on-hand are among the findings included in CliftonLarsonAllen's sweeping Skilled Nursing Facility Cost Comparison Report. Skilled nursing facilities saw a decrease in occupancy rates from 91.9% in 2010 to 90.4% in 2014, according to the report.

title: Workforce transformation [Webinar]
description: Find out in an upcoming webinar how Newton Medical Center optimized their labor utilization and also increased patient throughput, improved cash flow, and boosted patient satisfaction. Tuesday, Oct. 6 - 2:00 – 3:00 p.m. CDT.
body: Find out in an upcoming webinar how Newton Medical Center optimized their labor utilization and also increased patient throughput, improved cash flow, and boosted patient satisfaction. Tuesday, Oct. 6 - 2:00 – 3:00 p.m. CDT.
